Machine learning techniques are used to develop surrogate models that capture the underlying dynamics of subgrid-scale processes in large-scale systems. These models can either learn the embeddings of subgrid-scale processes or simulate them accurately to be fed into large-scale processes. This paper studies an extended version of the Lorenz 96 system, which consists of three equations for slow, intermediate, and fast variables, providing a fitting prototype for multi-scale, spatio-temporal chaos, and complex climate dynamics.

A data-driven model based on echo state networks (ESN) is developed, specifically for climate modeling. This model can predict the spatio-temporal chaotic evolution of the Lorenz system for several Lyapunov timescales. The results show that the ESN model outperforms deep learning techniques, such as recurrent neural networks (RNN) with long short-term memory (LSTM) and artificial neural networks, by factors of 3 to 10 in terms of prediction horizon.

The ESN model has the potential to be a powerful method for surrogate modeling and data-driven prediction in the climate community.

Introduction

There has been significant effort in recent times to apply deep learning to parameterize complex non-linear physical processes in climate models, particularly for clouds and deep convection (Rasp et al., 2018; Gentine et al., 2018). This is due to the high computational expense required to resolve subgrid-scale processes such as clouds, gravity waves, submesoscale eddies, and sea ice (Collins et al., 2006). Machine learning can provide a solution to this challenge by offering data-driven surrogate models of subgrid-scale physics that require high resolution (Reichstein et al., 2019).

In such cases, the surrogate model can either feed parametrized values into the climate model or learn the effects of subgrid-scale processes on the large-scale circulation in the climate model through observation or simulation of large-scale data. This paper proposes a data-driven solution to the multi-scale climate system represented by the 3-tier Lorenz 96 equations (Thornes et al., 2017).

The proposed data-driven model is restricted to train only on the low-frequency, large-amplitude variable over a training period and is expected to freely predict this variable in future time steps by learning the hidden embeddings of the intermediate and high-frequency variables that are coupled with the large-scale variable (see section 2). This system exhibits fully chaotic multi-scale dynamics and serves as a fitting prototype to test a modified echo state network (Jaeger, 2001), which has been previously found to be promising in systems exhibiting chaotic dynamics (Pathak et al., 2018).

The network provides predictions up to multiple Lyapunov exponents (or earth-days) and outperforms state-of-the-art deep learning approaches such as RNN-LSTM and previously reported prediction horizons by fully connected neural networks (Dueben & Bauer, 2018).

Multi-Scale Lorenz 96 System

The 3-tier multi-scale Lorenz system is governed by the following non-linear ordinary differential equations (ODEs):

dXk/dt = Xk-1(Xk+1 - Xk-2) + F - b * ΣjYj;k
dYj;k/dt = -cYj+1;k(Yj+2;k - Yj-1;k) - cYj;k + h * bXk - h * e * ΣiZi;j;k
dZi;j;k/dt = eZi-1;j;k(Zi+1;j;k - Zi-2;j;k) - gZi;j;k + h * eYj;k

In these equations, F = 20 is a large-scale forcing term that makes the system highly chaotic, while b = c = e = d = g = 10 and h = 1 ensure a variation in scale of amplitude and frequency of the three variables. The vector field X has 8 elements.
